text: so good morning and welcome to the first session in the big data track uh thanks for coming to reinvent i hope you all
enjoyed the keynote this morning um from andy very exciting for me to watch um a bunch of the stuff that we talked about
and i hope you all found it good too so this is the first breakout session in the big data track the big data state of
the union so what are we going to talk about and what would we like you to be able to leave this session with so this is a 100
level session it's the kind of the mini keynote for the big data track and it's an introductory session where
we'd like to spend some time i have two great speakers who are joining me scott hagerdone from analect
and lisa green from the common crawl so we can hear in their words the kind of things that they're doing and that
enable them with big data so we'd like you to leave this session having a kind of idea about
how we're thinking about what we do for you as our customers or our potential customers with big data and then hearing
in in the exact words of one of our customers how some of the building blocks and some of
the services that we developed can be useful spend a little bit of time overviewing what those building blocks are that we
provide lisa is going to spend some time talking about big open data and how the cloud
can help with that and then kind of give you a signpost there are a lot of other deep sessions if you if there's anything
in this presentation this morning that you find interesting and you want to go and learn more about whether it's
elastic mapreduce redshift data pipeline or any of those other services there are
a lot of other deep sessions that you can go and learn some more so that's the kind of thing we'd like to get to get out of the
session what do we want to do from a big data point of view at aws what do we want to enable you
to do we want to provide you with a very broad range of tools and technologies
so that you can work productively with data at any scale whether that's from gigabytes to terabytes to petalites and
so on and a whole choice of tools services that are both broad and deep to
support any kind of imaginable use case that you can think of from the point of view of working with and processing your
big data we also want to make sure that we're very clear along this continuum that we
want to give you the choice we want to give you the choice that if you want as you heard in the keynote this morning
as you're going to hear in some of the case studies we want you to be able to invest your capital we want you to be able to invest
your resources into doing the right things for your business not doing undifferentiated heavy lifting so if
you're going to run a data warehouse if you're going to run a hadoop cluster we would love to do that undifferentiated
heavy lifting on your behalf so you don't have to procure infrastructure you don't have to have people administering
it you can focus on dealing with your data but we also want to give you some choice
we participated in a panel recently talking about um different version different distributions of hadoop and
you kind of the theme was what's the right hadoop distribution and to a certain extent we don't have an opinion
we have a set of options for you so you can choose what you want to use if you'd like to use amazon elastic mapreduce and
have hadoop taken care of for you we would love you to do that from a database point of view if you've got
needs for a nosql database we would very much like you to use dynamodb if it provides the capabilities and the features that you want but if you want
to go and deploy something where you have absolutely full administrative control and deploy your own infrastructure in the aws cloud then
we're more than happy for you to do that as well so we want to provide you with a lot of different choices you can have the service managed for you or you can
do some work to build your own if that's what you would prefer to do and then also have the choice of
deploying your applications and deploy and working with your data in a place that's convenient for you we've got a
set of regions and availability zones right now and we're only going to be adding to them as time goes on
so when we think about big data we have a concept of something that we call the data timeline
going from the kind of the production and generation of the data on one side all the way to the other end where we
would think about how we can collaborate and share with that data with people later on
now i think we all know there's no problem generating data now any customer i talk to it's not a problem that they
don't have an ability to generate logs to analyze or other pieces of data they want to look at
but it's the other things that can traditionally be constrained whether that's smaller startup organizations or
large enterprise organizations being able to process that data being able to store
that data do the right kind of computational analytics and then ultimately share it these are the things
that when i talk to customers tend to be more of the the problems
we have some you know alex who talked about this the volume of data generated is is is really increasing but some
customers feel that maybe the ability to analyze that data is going to be more of a challenge
so we really want to think about how how utility computing can remove those
constraints and whether that's for smaller organizations who know they're going to be dealing with a lot of data
and we've got examples later in the presentation of those types of organizations whether it's traditional organizations who have a lot of data and
they just want a way to be able to process it in a way that they couldn't do before whether it's what lisa's going to talk
about later on that you know with it with a credit card and a data set that's stored in aws anyone can do these really
useful kind of um computations and processing we really believe that utility computing can remove these
constraints and we want to get to a place where that data timeline is without friction
for you so all the damage all the data that's generated you can process that you can use these building blocks that
we have to offer you to get value out of that um so to make that more real before we
start talking about some of these building blocks i'm going to ask scott hagendorn who the ceo of analect who's
kindly agreed to join us i'd like to invite scott on stage and he's going to talk about how utility computing and some adverse
building blocks have helped him so please welcome scott on stage
thank you so uh when i was asked i'm an

so first thing i thought i would do is reveal a bit of a dirty little secret if

of muckraking right now if you will how would you describe your dog's

very smart and yours he's independent you know
he knows what he likes it's pretty hard to fool oh my god they're describing themselves
this your first group the focus group is where big ideas come from right now
in the advertising industry it's a culture of m m's of one-way mirrors of
people watching people's dogs eat dog food and describe themselves this is where the big insight typically comes
from for the beginning of an advertising campaign and oftentimes somebody like myself will make up some kind of
word like joy bombing or something fun that then makes it all the way down the equation and oh yeah we
should be talking about joy bombing people are really into joy bombing these days and then boom you get a big idea
and then let's talk about how the go to market strategy typically works it's a bit of a game of telephone um
constantly losing some of its uh integrity with people talking to people saying okay do you have this audience do
you have that audience no i don't have one but i have one that kind of looks like this and ultimately a billion dollars 500 billion dollars will move
based on some hypotheses on where an audience is where a target is what they look like what's going to be most
resonant for them and ultimately when you put some weak idea potentially that's been coming out of a focus group
with a not so great marketing and go to market strategy you end up with what i equate to a loose
nuclear warhead in the market you don't know if it's going to work you
do know that it's going to hit somebody you might have slim pickens from dr strangelove writing the nuke down but no
one knows if it's actually going to be effective no one knows if it's going to be resonant because inherently it's all
qualitatively based and what's going on right now is is the industry is actually changing uh the
culture is changing and it's very it's it's tough for some people to swallow i'll let the mushroom cloud happen that
one apparently worked because data is inherently changing our business
marketing is becoming about a data business and a great example of that i'm trying not
to knock the computer off here is if you look at vatican square from 2005
when they elected two popes ago versus 2013
our industry now is awash in data the signals the contextual geographic behavioral and
demographic infinite amounts of data that are coming from devices are constantly changing our
industry and so we are moving from an industry that was all qualitatively
based and struggling to become an industry that's more quantitatively based and if you get down to what's really
happening which is that tv is shifting into devices all of the devices that the tv and the
content is shifting out to give off a huge amount of data exhaust like i said contextual geographic
behavioral demographic data sets mobile data sets tons and tons of data now in our
previous environment when we tried to deal with that much
data to create tools to create applications to change the marketplace
our servers exploded my cto and i dean and my engineering team and the aggregate knowledge team

together so anyway the server's exploded so what we ultimately need to change the marketplace is we need a stronger
cloud-based environment and what we've put together
is essentially a complete new cloud-based infrastructure to run our advertising practice
with a lot of the a lot of the technologies that paul was referring to a few minutes ago so we've built out a
cloud-based environment where all of our data goes into including and most importantly all the digital data that we
have running through the holding company for all digital touch points which we work with aggregate knowledge on we're
the first big company i think to move in this direction so essentially we've built a huge cloud-based environment to create
new tools new technologies new applications to do marketing and to do advertising and we're moving quickly to
a place where marketing is is on an always-on state and increasingly becoming somewhat
artificially aware some people refer to it as programmatic where there is a loop between
performance and insight and activation or how you actively go to market with advertising dollars
infinite marketing or programmatic marketing you could really use either way to look at it and what we're increasingly doing in
that cloud-based data environment is we get all the digital data that we have coming out of the third the kind of
first party spaces and we're oftentimes now fusing it with clients crm data sets
sales data sets this is where amazon becomes very interesting for us because of the amount of data both that we're
able to work with them on from their advertising practice perspective as well as the advertising uh the data that we're allowed to increasingly generating
and so i'll show you now a couple of the applications that we've actually built onto onto this environment
so this one sort of replaces a focus group we built this for an automotive client
it's fusing jd power data polk data their first party crm and sales data of
people that are coming off of lease or that have bought a car before and it tells you everything you need to
know about this audience what do they look like what are their media habits what influences them why do they buy
what they buy and this has become essentially the planning tool that is the jumping off point now for coming up with insights
and for coming up with creative ideas instead of it being qualitatively based in a focus group
it's becoming inherently quantitatively based we've also rebuilt sort of how
we go to market from an advertising perspective as wall street changed so we basically mirrored wall street and we
now increasingly are trading media uh and trading advertising like stock in
real time um and the industry is going this way which is again very disruptive
uh so our trading interface and this is built within the data management platform environment with aggregate knowledge but this is building
essentially right now an algorithm that's both geographically based and weather-based to activate advertising
inventory in real time so essentially you're building your own trading algorithms in real time to take them to
market so planning has become or coming up with the insights has become increasingly quantitative and
advertising itself is becoming increasingly programmatically driven like stock and then on the back end of it
we have our analytics performance system so to paul's point about moving from the
data generation all the way down the continuum this is where we're actually sharing the performance results directly with the
client and all the computation is happening behind the scenes in the cloud-based environment we've put all the logic in and we've piped all the
data into it and this is now all integrated into one software platform for doing marketing
and advertising that did not exist before and could not exist before we entered the cloud environment
two more quick examples we talk about how much data we're ultimately generating
uh this is where it ultimately all flows into so this is looking at cross across
multiple clients across multiple industries across multiple geographies
at the sheer volume of data and impressions that we're able to work with so at the core
of everything i just showed you planning trading analytics there is a data heart
to it where everything flows into it in the cloud-based environment as i mentioned so just to wrap it up
if i can leave you with anything is that we're headed into a space where marketing is infinite is always on
is aware quantitatively it's a combination of hpc and big data
and we're enabling that through through cloud-based services with amazon with aggregate knowledge
we've built a very interesting infrastructure where we are combining infinite storage
capabilities with infinite data capabilities and then infinite computing capabilities to build
our new set of tools and increasingly it's becoming artificially aware which i wanted to
introduce my new company to you skynet um
and you can anticipate that in the future i will have marketing drones

the point of view there's no administration for customers very low latency
single the millisecond latency typically and running on ssd storage nodes at the back end
very very easy for customers to scale there's no work to do from a planning infrastructure point of view
performance is very predictable and i hope you saw some of that earlier when andy was discussing that and something

if you start small that's fine you want to grow later that's fine too and we do all of that infrastructural

so spot the spot market this concept of being able to bid for excess compute capacity so you can guess that typically
the price is going to be significantly lower than on demand can mean if you've got work that you need to speed up you could add more you could use some spot
nodes instead of having to use uh on-demand pricing and you still get
access and underlying control to those instances that are there conceptually works pretty in a pretty
simple fashion for customers store your data in the first place and code in an amazon s3 bucket
choose to launch your cluster make some decisions about what you're going to run on the cluster the programs you're going
to run and so on the cluster will start taking the data from s3 and ultimately
you can choose to have that data stored back in s3 shut the cluster down and do it for a very short period of time
so you've got lots of flexibility there instead of having to run this on-premises cluster that's going to be a fixed size and effectively able to do a
fixed amount of work you can start with one size of cluster if you need to do your work more quickly
you could resize your cluster you can add nodes you can make it bigger you can start it bigger you could have multiple clusters that are different sizes
and it might not be about doing one piece of work it might be that you need to do different pieces
of work and with that data set being stored in s3 you could have multiple clusters that are all running against
that data set at one period of time uh one customer who's not in the presentation but who i was talking to

kind of the main original broadcasters in the uk channel 4 is a public service broadcaster but one that still sells um
still sells advertising so they had this huge amount of log data that they were finding it very they couldn't really

access analysis of web data big data analysis of web data

and when i say open i mean both gratis that it won't cost you anything to access our data

it's web crawl data which is tremendously valuable data the web
is a digital copy of our world and being digital that means you can run
